items.title: Add flake8-print
items.body:
We do not want print statements in our code (use `logging`).
Flake8-print is a plugin for detection of print statements, and can be added to our style guide enforcer.
See [flake8-print](https://pypi.org/project/flake8-print/).
It should be added to the pre-commit routine.

items.title: Data edit api for new website
items.body:
As discussed, this api can edit some meta-features of the dataset:
List of  meta-features can  be edited/ updated via data_edit API call, see PR https://github.com/openml/OpenML/pull/1044

1. description
2. creator
3. collection_date
4. language
5. citation
6. original_data_url
7. paper_url

These meta-features/ data will just need to call create_dataset api and create a new version: **(python api)**
1. attributes
2. data - the data itself
3. default_target_attribute
4. ignore_attribute
5. row_id_attribute

After the data_edit API is ready, I can create a single **python API** to handle both of these cases.
Based on the arguments (None or otherwise). We can either create a new dataset or call the data_edit API.

items.title: Better error messages for string constraints
items.body:
#### Description
I often hear users complain that they don't know what to do when `create_dataset` complains about string constraints. Typically this is because people used a space (' ') in the name (I'm not actually sure why we don't allow that) or a special character in the description.

Could we maybe return a more informative general error message, like 'Character ' ' is not allowed in field x'?

Alternatively, let the python API replace spaces in the dataset name with underscores automatically, and replace special characters with '?' or ' '.


#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
Example:
```python
import openml

my_dataset = create_dataset(
    name="My cool dataset",
    description="foo",
    creator="bar"
    contributor=None,
    collection_date='01-01-2011',
    language='English',
    licence=None,
    default_target_attribute='label',
    row_id_attribute=None,
    ignore_attribute=None,
    citation="foo",
    attributes='auto',
    data=df,
    version_label='1.0',
)
```

#### Expected Results
A more informative general error message, like 'Character ' ' is not allowed in field x'?
Or: replace the 'bad' characters automatically

#### Actual Results
A hard-to-read stack trace:
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
```

items.title: More convenient feature name extraction
items.body:
#### Description
When getting data in the dataframe format, things are generally easy. However, when getting data in the array format and separately getting the feature names, there are some unexpected things:
- The names of ignored attributes are included when calling dataset.features. These features are not present in the data (X) itself
- The class feature name is included
- Features are returned as objects, not just a list of names.

All of these things do make sense in some way, but they make it a bit inconvenient to get the feature names. I ultimately end of writing something like:

```
features = [f.name for i,f in dates.features.items() if f.name not in dates.ignore_attribute][:-1]
```

That seems not so nice for novice users. Would it make sense to add a convenience function for that?

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
See code above

#### Expected Results
A method like dataset.retrieve_feature_names that returns a list of feature names that are present in the loaded data.

#### Actual Results
No such function, have to write this myself every time.

#### Versions
Darwin-19.3.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.7.3 (default, Mar 27 2019, 16:54:48)
[Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]
NumPy 1.18.1
SciPy 1.4.1
Scikit-Learn 0.22.1
OpenML 0.11.0dev

items.title: Package should not configure logging without being asked to do so
items.body:
I think this is a followup to #736. I think the fact that OpenML is configuring logger at all is problematic, especially because it is doing at the `import openml` time without any way for anyone to prevent that. Currently, there is such code segment;

```
logger = logging.getLogger(__name__)


def configure_logging(console_output_level: int, file_output_level: int):
    """ Sets the OpenML logger to DEBUG, with attached Stream- and FileHandler. """
    # Verbosity levels as defined (https://github.com/openml/OpenML/wiki/Client-API-Standards)
    # don't match Python values directly:
    verbosity_map = {0: logging.WARNING, 1: logging.INFO, 2: logging.DEBUG}

    openml_logger = logging.getLogger('openml')
    openml_logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)
    message_format = '[%(levelname)s] [%(asctime)s:%(name)s] %(message)s'
    output_formatter = logging.Formatter(message_format, datefmt='%H:%M:%S')

    console_stream = logging.StreamHandler()
    console_stream.setFormatter(output_formatter)
    console_stream.setLevel(verbosity_map[console_output_level])

    one_mb = 2**20
    log_path = os.path.join(cache_directory, 'openml_python.log')
    file_stream = logging.handlers.RotatingFileHandler(log_path, maxBytes=one_mb, backupCount=1)
    file_stream.setLevel(verbosity_map[file_output_level])
    file_stream.setFormatter(output_formatter)

    openml_logger.addHandler(console_stream)
    openml_logger.addHandler(file_stream)
    return console_stream, file_stream
```

And that method is always called inside `__init__`.

Libraries should not do that. Libraries should log things to logger, but consumers of the libraries should then configure how logging happens. For example, inside `__main__` section or something like that.

The problem with the code above is that it writes to the file system just by importing a package. That can make problems on various computing platforms, especially grid computing, where one cannot just write around the shared systems.

`openml_logger.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)` is unnecessary. Every logger in fact starts with `NOTSET` logging level which is even lower (numerical 0) than `DEBUG` (numerical 10). But setting it might prevent somebody else to configure it before importing `openml`. So I suggest this is removed.

Adding handlers to the logger is generally OK, but might be unnecessary. For example, the user of the `openml` package might not be a person sitting in front of the interpreter, but the system. Which would configure that all logging is send to a central logging service over the network. Having to know that you also have to disable/remove some handlers added to the logger seems tricky.

I suggest this is made as a function one can call to configure, but not something which is done by default at import time. Or maybe one can enable it in the config file.

Alternatively, if you really want this behavior, I suggest this is done at the first call to OpenML API functions, and not at the import.

items.body: By using a git hook

items.title: __version__ is imported with `from openml import *`
items.body:
Not that you should ever really want to use `import *`, but '\_\_version\_\_' is listed in `openml\__init__.py:__all__`  which means it gets imported:
```
>>> from openml import *
>>> __version__
'0.9.0'
```
This is generally not done, so we might remove '\_\_version\_\_' from our `__all__` list.

items.title: Simplify run_model_on_task
items.body:
Currently, we require the user to create a task object:
```python
from sklearn import ensemble
from openml import tasks, runs

clf = ensemble.RandomForestClassifier()
task = tasks.get_task(3954)
run = runs.run_model_on_task(clf, task)
run.publish()
```
which is actually unnecessary and should be possible like this, too:
```
from sklearn import ensemble
from openml import tasks, runs

clf = ensemble.RandomForestClassifier()
run = runs.run_model_on_task(clf, 3954)
run.publish()
```

items.title: list_evaluations_setup() fails when number of evaluations not a multiple of 100
items.body:
`np.split` looks to split the array into _N_ equal spaced arrays wherein N is 100 [here](https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/develop/openml/evaluations/functions.py#L332). As a result, it appears that for any combination of input where the number of evaluations returned is not a multiple of 100, this function will throw an error.


To recreate:

##### what works
`import openml`
`df = openml.evaluations.list_evaluations_setups(function='predictive_accuracy', flow=[8353], task=[6], output_format='dataframe', parameters_in_separate_columns=True)`

##### what fails
`df = openml.evaluations.list_evaluations_setups(function='predictive_accuracy', flow=[5891], task=[37], output_format='dataframe', parameters_in_separate_columns=True)`

##### comparison
Since `list_evaluations_setup` calls `list_evaluations` internally.

`df = openml.evaluations.list_evaluations(function='predictive_accuracy', flow=[8353], task=[6], output_format='dataframe')`
`print(len(df))  #1000` 

`df = openml.evaluations.list_evaluations(function='predictive_accuracy', flow=[5891], task=[37], output_format='dataframe')`
`print(len(df))  #2429`

items.title: Allow several instances of same flow within one flow
items.body:
Right now we can't have more than one scaler or imputer in a pipeline/column transformer.
@mfeurer has some work-arounds (creating new classes for second instances) but that's a hassle and means that we'll have different flows for essentially the same step.

items.title: Can't create flow from ColumnTransformer
items.body:
Trying to write a general ColumnTransformer to run a decision stump.
I tried passing the feature masks as boolean arrays, which broke. Converting to lists of integers works a bit further but also breaks.

```python
import openml
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.pipeline import make_pipeline
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.preprocessing import OneHotEncoder, StandardScaler
from sklearn.impute import SimpleImputer
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeClassifier

def get_frequent_task(did):
    tasks = openml.tasks.list_tasks(task_type_id=1, data_id=did)
    most_frequent_task = pd.Series({task: len(openml.runs.list_runs(task=[task])) for task in tasks}).index[0]
    return (most_frequent_task, tasks[most_frequent_task]['NumberOfInstances'])

dataset_id = 61
dataset = openml.datasets.get_dataset(dataset_id)

X, y, categorical_ind, feature_names = dataset.get_data(target=dataset.default_target_attribute, dataset_format='array')
categorical_ind = np.array(categorical_ind)
cat_idx, = np.where(categorical_ind)
cont_idx, = np.where(~categorical_ind)

clf = make_pipeline(ColumnTransformer([('cat', make_pipeline(SimpleImputer(strategy='most_frequent'), OneHotEncoder()), cat_idx.tolist()),
                                       ('cont', make_pipeline(SimpleImputer(strategy='median'), StandardScaler()), cont_idx.tolist())])          
                , DecisionTreeClassifier(max_depth=1))
if not categorical_ind.any():
    clf[0].set_params(cat='drop')
if not (~categorical_ind).any():
    clf[0].set_params(cont='drop')
hotencoded = clf[:-1].fit_transform(X)

bla = openml.runs.run_model_on_task(model=clf, task=get_frequent_task(dataset_id), return_flow=True)
```
TypeError: Second item of tuple does not match assumptions. Expected OpenMLFlow, got <class 'str'>

I guess having a "drop" transformer in ColumnTransformer doesn't work?

items.title: Rename arguments of list_evaluations to indicate they expect lists of ids
items.body:
See also #796. It was a step forward, but the argument names still don't convey that we are looking for a list (i.e. argument name should be plural) or ids as opposed to OpenML objects (e.g. by a suffix `_id`).

I would argue that we also should update the type hints (to `Optional[List[Union[str, int]]]`) and add parameter descriptions in the docstring.

items.title: Suggestion: add function to get tasks for a dataset?
items.body:
@janvanrijn suggested this as part of his review of PR #791 (https://github.com/openml/openml-python/pull/791#discussion_r330118731)

One possibility would be to have an independent function:

```
def get_tasks_for_dataset(
    dataset_id: int,
    task_type_id: int,
    estimation_procedure: str,
    status: str,
    check_target_attribute: bool,
) -> List:
    pass
```

alternatively, one could make this a method for the `OpenMLDataset`:
```
def get_tasks(
    self,
    task_type_id: int,
    estimation_procedure: str,
    status: str,
    check_target_attribute: bool,
) -> List:
    pass
```
what do you think?

items.title: list_evaluations_setups to have complicated setup obtain mechanism
items.body:
IMO this code can be simplified by relying on the pagination function of the general listing function? 

This avoids having duplicate complicated code blocks 

(note that there are a lot of testing functions keeping the pagination function of listing working)

items.title: openml-python does not recognize corrupt dataset.pkl.py3 file
items.body:
People are experiencing issues downloading dataset `41081` [here](https://github.com/ML-course/ML-course/issues/19).
Investigation is on-going, but it looks like the Python process gets killed when pickling the dataset to disk.
Subsequent loads of the cached data fail because the `dataset.pkl.py3` file is created (and sits at 0 bytes). Because the file exists it is attempted to be loaded without further sanity checks. I think the correct behavior would to check for this faulty file and if it exists either (1) raise an error or (2) delete the file, attempt to pickle is again, and raise an error only if this fails. I would prefer option 2.

edit: to clarify, this issue is about trying to mitigate the effect of corrupt files in cache. Not about the fact that the process gets killed (possibly during pickling). That warrants a separate issue which I will open after we have some more information from the linked issue.

items.title: Guide on how to create and publish openml-python extensions
items.body:
* Rip out everything except the extension class which extends the interface
* Register the extension: https://openml.github.io/openml-python/master/generated/openml.extensions.register_extension.html#openml.extensions.register_extension
* Set up openml-python extensions organization
* Unit tests: every new repo need to set up own CI
* Documentation: also local?

items.title: Install from source distribution during unit tests
items.body: We should install the package from a source distribution during unit testing to make sure that end users can install it, too. Also, we should use the `twine check` utility to make sure that the source distribution would be accepted by pypi.

items.title: Problems with get_metric_fn and sklearn.metrics for multiclass classification tasks
items.body:
Hi there, 

I am trying to produce various evaluations metrics for existing runs using get_metric_fn. I have no problem doing this for binary classification tasks, but I am running into problems for multiclass classification. Here are a few examples with regard to average_precision_score:

Binary classification (e.g. task 49) works fine:
```{python}
import openml
from sklearn.metrics import average_precision_score
run = openml.runs.get_run(10288928)
run.get_metric_fn(average_precision_score)
```

Running the same code on a multiclass classification (e.g. task 146821) run yields an error as expected:
```{python}
import openml
from sklearn.metrics import average_precision_score
run = openml.runs.get_run(10261809)
run.get_metric_fn(average_precision_score)
```
ValueError: multiclass format is not supported

When I add the 'average' argument for multiclass classification, I get another error: 
```{python}
import openml
from sklearn.metrics import average_precision_score
run = openml.runs.get_run(10261809)
run.get_metric_fn(average_precision_score(average = 'macro'))
```
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-151-4986f5df7345> in <module>
      3 
      4 run = openml.runs.get_run(10261809)
----> 5 run.get_metric_fn(average_precision_score(average = 'macro'))

TypeError: average_precision_score() missing 2 required positional arguments: 'y_true' and 'y_score'

My question: Is it possible to run sklearn metrics on OpenML multiclass classification tasks?

@amueller

items.title: Issues when running ColumnTransformer on OpenML tasks
items.body:
Hi there, 

I am running a pipeline that involves the sklearn ColumnTransformer on OpenML tasks. I am basically trying to apply OneHotEncoder to categorical variables and StandardScaler to numeric variables - very simple stuff. 
I know that the OpenML datasets come with a mask indicating categorical variables. I have no problems when I am using the mask to run pipelines with ColumnTransformer on the OpenML datasets. 
However, when I am using run_model_on_task and I try to run the same pipeline on an OpenML task object I am getting error messages. Here is an example: 

```python
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.pipeline import Pipeline, make_pipeline
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler, OneHotEncoder
from sklearn.compose import ColumnTransformer
from sklearn.svm import SVC
from sklearn.impute import SimpleImputer

import openml

# get task
task = openml.tasks.get_task(17)

# get dataset object 
data = openml.datasets.get_dataset(task.dataset_id)

# get relevant info from dataset
X, y, categorical_indicator, attribute_names = data.get_data(dataset_format='array',
                                                            target=data.default_target_attribute)

# transform data into pandas onjects
X = pd.DataFrame(X, columns=attribute_names)
y = pd.Series(y)

# create masks for columntransformer
cat = categorical_indicator
num = [not k for k in categorical_indicator]

# create numeric and categorical transformers
numeric_transformer = Pipeline(steps=[
('scaler', StandardScaler())])

categorical_transformer = Pipeline(steps=[
('onehot', OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown='ignore'))])

# create column transformer
preprocessor = ColumnTransformer(
transformers=[
('num', numeric_transformer, num),
('cat', categorical_transformer, cat)])

# initialize classifier
clf = SVC(gamma = 'scale')

# create pipeline
pipe = make_pipeline(SimpleImputer(strategy='most_frequent'), preprocessor, clf)

# run pipeline on dataframe
pipe_fit = pipe.fit(X, y)

# run pipeline on the task
run = openml.runs.run_model_on_task(pipe, task)
```

items.title: Cannot load sparse datasets with categorical variables any more
items.body:
Can be reproduced with:

```
import openml

openml.datasets.get_dataset(395)
```

items.title: update scikit-learn dependency?
items.body:
The current tests fail with later scikit-learn releases in several places, because the code relies on classes and attributes that have been removed.
I would suggest using 0.20 from Sept 2018 as minimum version.
That introduced the current ColumnTransformer and SimpleImputer and OneHotEncoder and so you'd be able to write current sklearn.

items.title: Python version requirements inconsistent
items.body:
I noticed in your `setup.py` file that you have [a requirement for Python version >= 3.5](https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/56fcc00cb16b102e4778c1f1dadd7d9919e9eca4/setup.py#L16), but you do not have a [`python_requires` keyword](https://packaging.python.org/guides/distributing-packages-using-setuptools/#python-requires), and you have the [Python 3.4 in your trove classifiers](https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/56fcc00cb16b102e4778c1f1dadd7d9919e9eca4/setup.py#L82).

I suggest adding `python_requires=">= 3.5"` to your `setup()` invocation and removing Python 3.4 from your trove classifiers.

(Adding this because it's relevant for `python_requires`, not because I have any evidence you don't already know it). When uploading your distributions, make sure to use [`twine`](https://pypi.org/project/twine/), instead of `setup.py upload`, since the latter is deprecated and some versions of `setuptools` have bugs that will cause problems for some users.

items.title: openml registers handler on root logger
items.body:
`openml` registers a streamhandler with the root logger, because [it uses `logging.basicConfig`](https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/develop/openml/config.py). That functions registers a `logging.StreamHandler` with the root logger if it does not yet have a handler. This means that logging of other packages may automatically be processed by this streamhandler. An example to demonstrate:

```python
import logging

if __name__ == '__main__':
    #  Commenting out the line below prevents `basicConfig` from registering a streamhandler
    #  logging.getLogger().addHandler(logging.NullHandler())
    
    log = logging.getLogger('mypackage')
    log.setLevel(logging.DEBUG)

    log.info("Message one")  # first call, no log handler registered
    import openml
    log.info("Message two")  # second call, log handler registered by openml
```
output:
```
[INFO] [14:47:46:mypackage] Message two
```

Due to the `logging.basicConfig` behavior, if a handler already is registered (such as is done in the commented out line), it will not add a `logging.StreamHandler`. So there is no output if the relevant line of code is commented out.

I also see a verbosity in the config defaults, but I don't see it used anywhere. Am I missing something?

I think adding a `logging.StreamHandler` to the root logger is undesirable behavior. Developers should have full autonomy over their logging handlers without resorting to adding `logging.NullHandler`. I think we should avoid using `logging.basicConfig` to set our streamhandler. Instead, we should register a streamhandler to an openml specific logger instead of the root (i.e. `log = logging.getLogger('openml')` or `log = logging.getLogger(__name__)`). We should make sure to take into account the verbosity level as defined in the config when doing so.

items.title: Guidelines for publishing OpenML-python extensions
items.body:
#### Description
OpenML has an extension API, and you can use it to connect other libraries to OpenML. It is however unclear how one should later up 'publish' this extension so that other people can use it.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
Here is an example of an extension that adds full support for Keras, MXnet, PyTorch and ONNX:
https://github.com/openml/openml-deeplearning/

It is currently a clone of the pull python API with the extension added in separate folders: https://github.com/openml/openml-deeplearning/tree/master/openml/extensions

Each folder has an extensions.py file and usually a config.py file with additional configuration functionality.

It also has documentation in the `examples` folder and test in the `tests` folder.

It is currently installable as a standalone package through pip. However, this may lead to divergence between this package and the core python API.

#### Expected Results
Clear guidelines on how extensions can be published and imported. It should allow independent testing and documentation.

If this makes sense, maybe also define a way to 'register' extensions so it is easier to find and install them.

Thanks!

items.title: New evaluation listing call that includes hyperparameters
items.body:
Currently, if one wants to download all hyperparameters and evaluations of a specific flow, they need to first download the list of evaluations (fast), and then download runs one by one to get the hyperparameters (slow).

This is a problem for the current Frontend, plus it also complicates downloading meta-data from the server (last time I tried this it worked but took a very long time).

Since this is such a common use case, should we add an API call for that? Basically something 
returning something like:
```
{
  "evaluations": {
    "evaluation": [
      {
        "run_id": "1",
        "task_id": "68",
        "flow_id": "61",
        "function": "area_under_roc_curve",
        "upload_time": "2014-04-06 23:30:40",
        "value": "0.839359",
        "array_data": "[0,0.99113,0.898048,0.874862,0.791282,0.807343,0.820674]",
        "setup_parameters": "parameter": [
            {
              "full_name": "weka.JRip(1)_F",
              "parameter_name": "F",
              "value": "3"
            },
           {
             "full_name": "weka.JRip(1)_N",
             "parameter_name": "N",
             "value": "2.0"
           },
           ...]
      }
```

Different options:
* Add it as an option `return_setups=true` to the current evaluation list call. It would only work if there is a specific flow and function, otherwise return an error.
* Add it as a new call `list_evaluations_and_setup(flow_id,function)
* Use the current setup/id call, but that has the same issue that you need to ask for the setups one by one, plus the evaluation list does not return the setup id. 

Thoughts?

#### Description
Hi there, I'm attempting to work with some datasets from OpenML using calls from the API [here](https://docs.openml.org/Python-API/).
Somehow, when I attempt to call a few functions with datasets, I get errors that suggest that there isn't any support although the API and examples on the site say that I should be able to make those calls. Examples are below

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
First, the following code
```python
import openml
ex = openml.datasets.get_dataset(1497)

X, y, categorical_indicator, attribute_names = ex.get_data(
    target=ex.default_target_attribute,
    dataset_format='dataframe'
)
```
yields the error ```TypeError: get_data() got an unexpected keyword argument 'dataset_format'```

Also, interestingly, the code ```openml.datasets.attributes_arff_from_df(ex)```
gives the error ```AttributeError: module 'openml.datasets' has no attribute 'attributes_arff_from_df'```, which I found odd because it suggests that I can't even call this using the openml library. 

#### Expected Results
I didn't expect the second piece of code to work since I didn't have the dataset as a dataframe (although if the first bit of code worked than I would have), but the error I got is different from what I was expecting (i.e. that the problem would be with the input, and not with openml.datasets not having the attribute). 

#### Versions

items.title: Quick summaries of openml objects
items.body:
#### Description
I often see users struggle with interpreting what an openml object (e.g. a dataset or a pipeline) really is and what it contains. For beginning users, it is also unclear what they can do to get more insight. Nobody likes to run `print(vars(flow)`, and going to the website to get more information is a bit troublesome (and not obvious).

What about we provide a summary() function for dataset, tasks, flows, and runs that provides a quick but rich overview of the object?

#### Expected Results
For instance, running something like
```python
import openml
data = openml.flows.get_dataset(1)
data.summary()
```
could output a snippet of the description, a small table with statistics, maybe even a small table with the first couple of rows and columns.

Likewise, running
```python
flow = openml.flows.get_flow(1)
flow.summary()
```
Could print out a list (or graph) of the pipeline components.

Likewise, `task.summary()` could return the task details, and `run.summary()` could return some run details and evaluation results.

In a notebook environment, you could even include some nice pandas tables and plots, but that will always work.

items.title: `sklearn_to_flow` raises TypeError on simple flow
items.body:
I found that the following simple example does not convert to an `OpenMLFlow` with `sklearn_to_flow` . I do not know *why* this happens (lists of lists?). The definition of a flow in code is also quite unclear and has a lots of gaps left with "TODO: add documentation".
```
import openml
from sklearn.preprocessing import OrdinalEncoder
openml.flows.sklearn_to_flow(OrdinalEncoder(categories=[[0,1],[0,1]]))
```
raises
```
... traceback ...
  File "D:\repositories/openml-python\openml\flows\sklearn_converter.py", line 534, in _extract_information_from_model
    raise TypeError(msg)
TypeError: Second item of tuple does not match assumptions. Expected OpenMLFlow, got <class 'numpy.float32'>
```

items.title: Feature request: study list
items.body:
OpenML API supports study listing, but I haven't implemented this in Python yet. Would be cool to add this.

https://test.openml.org/api/v1/study/list/status/all

Legal filters:
- status {in preparation, active, deactivated}
- uploader
- offset
- status

I believe the api docs are currently under review.

items.title: test_list_datasets_with_high_size_parameter  fails often
items.body:
This function seems to fail often. 
```
    def test_list_datasets_with_high_size_parameter(self):
        datasets_a = openml.datasets.list_datasets()
        datasets_b = openml.datasets.list_datasets(size=np.inf)
    
>       self.assertEqual(len(datasets_a), len(datasets_b))
E       AssertionError: 1505 != 1506
```

My assumption: due to multi threaded testing, in between the two list dataset calls some new datasets have been uploaded. 

We should redesign this test case.

items.title: upload time and error message missing from list_runs
items.body:
#### Description
When you list runs, upload time and error message are not shown, even though they are returned by the OpenML API. It would be very handy if these can be added.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```python
import openml as oml
runs = oml.runs.list_runs(task=[2])
runs
```

#### Expected Results
```python
{110: {'flow_id': 76,
          'run_id': 110,
          'setup_id': 17,
          'task_id': 2,
          'uploader': 1,
          'upload_time': '2016-04-06 23:30:40',
          'error_message': []
}
```
#### Actual Results
```python
{110: {'flow_id': 76,
  'run_id': 110,
  'setup_id': 17,
  'task_id': 2,
  'uploader': 1},
```

#### Versions
Linux-4.14.79+-x86_64-with-Ubuntu-18.04-bionic
Python 3.6.7 (default, Oct 22 2018, 11:32:17) 
[GCC 8.2.0]
NumPy 1.14.6
SciPy 1.1.0
Scikit-Learn 0.20.2
OpenML 0.8.0

items.title: Better error messages on listing queries
items.body:
#### Description
When you want to list items using the listing calls, you have to provide lists (e.g. a list of tasks). If you don't know this you get a cryptic error message 'TypeError: 'int' object is not iterable'

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce

```python
import openml as oml
runs = oml.runs.list_runs(task=2)
```

#### Expected Results
Either detect that it is an integer instead of a list and handle internally, or provide a clearer error message that a list must be provided.

#### Actual Results
```python

/usr/local/lib/python3.6/dist-packages/openml/runs/functions.py in _list_runs(id, task, setup, flow, uploader, display_errors, **kwargs)
   1002         api_call += "/run/%s" % ','.join([str(int(i)) for i in id])
   1003     if task is not None:
-> 1004         api_call += "/task/%s" % ','.join([str(int(i)) for i in task])
   1005     if setup is not None:
   1006         api_call += "/setup/%s" % ','.join([str(int(i)) for i in setup])

TypeError: 'int' object is not iterable
```


#### Versions
openml 0.8.0 (fresh pip install)

items.title: duplicate functions tags
items.body: all entities (`data`, `flow`, etc) have a `push_tag` and `remove_tag` function, but this functionality is also implemented in `utils.py` with the function `_tag_entity` (tags and untags). Let's drop either of these functionalities (or at least make the `push_tag` and `remove_tag` functions use `_tag_entity` as backend)

items.title: Klaverjas Dataset

#### Description

Get data fails while trying to retrieve the examples and labels of the Klaverjas dataset.
#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```python
import openml

task = openml.tasks.get_task(168739)

dataset = task.get_dataset()

x, y, categorical = dataset.get_data(
    target=dataset.default_target_attribute,
    return_categorical_indicator=True
)
```

Dataset 41228 not compatible, PyOpenML cannot handle string features

items.title: Can't download dataset metadata without downloading the dataset itself
items.body:
#### Description
There are situations where one only wants to see the meta-data of a given dataset. The current get_dataset always downloads and parses the dataset itself. This is slow(!), and can cause errors if the files are really large. 

It would be nice to have an option (or another call) to download the meta-data only.

To make matters worse, the arff parser requires many times the file size for the download and parsing. E.g. downloading a 2GB dataset requires more than 16GB disk space. This fails in colab notebooks: they crash because of disk space limits. I would download the csv version directly, but this requires the file url or file_id, neither of which are returned by list_dataset and thus have to be retrieved with get_dataset. So, there is currently no way to download larger OpenML dataset into colab notebooks without manually looking up the file_ids.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
Download any large dataset (e.g. SVHN): 
```
openml.datasets.get_dataset(41081)
```

#### Expected Results
An OpenMLDataset object without the actual dataset, or a dict with the meta-data.

#### Actual Results
get_dataset is very slow, or crashes if disk space is not sufficient.

#### Versions
Darwin-18.2.0-x86_64-i386-64bit
Python 3.6.4 |Anaconda custom (64-bit)| (default, Jan 16 2018, 12:04:33)
[GCC 4.2.1 Compatible Clang 4.0.1 (tags/RELEASE_401/final)]
NumPy 1.15.3
SciPy 1.1.0
Scikit-Learn 0.20.0
OpenML 0.7.0

items.title: dataset_id referenced before assignment
items.body:
#### Description

While trying to get the run with id 186276, the error dataset_id referenced before assignment was raised. 

The error is happening here:

https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/7c0a77d232a64da76be18bbce76e4bb8aeb4155b/openml/runs/functions.py#L883

Taking a quick look into the function throwing it, this seems to be the problem:
https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/7c0a77d232a64da76be18bbce76e4bb8aeb4155b/openml/runs/functions.py#L804-L807

The run at https://www.openml.org/api/v1/run/186276 does not seem to have a dataset field at all. 

Should this run be removed ? @mfeurer  @janvanrijn 
#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```
import openml

run = openml.runs.get_run(186276)
```

items.title: Reinstantiating flow with ColumnTransformer does not set back the transformer values
items.body:
#### Description
related to #602, but different (this one is about flows)

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```
import logging
import numpy as np
import openml
import sklearn.compose
import sklearn.ensemble
import sklearn.feature_selection
import sklearn.impute
import sklearn.preprocessing


openml.config.apikey = 'd488d8afd93b32331cf6ea9d7003d4c3'
openml.config.server = 'https://test.openml.org/api/v1/'

task = openml.tasks.get_task(6)  # letter dataset

def get_model():
    numeric_transformer = sklearn.pipeline.make_pipeline(
        sklearn.preprocessing.Imputer(),
        sklearn.preprocessing.StandardScaler())

    categorical_transformer = sklearn.pipeline.make_pipeline(
        sklearn.impute.SimpleImputer(strategy='constant', fill_value=-1),
        sklearn.preprocessing.OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown='ignore'))

    nominal_indices = task.get_dataset().get_features_by_type('nominal', [task.target_name])
    numeric_indices = task.get_dataset().get_features_by_type('numeric', [task.target_name])

    transformer = sklearn.compose.ColumnTransformer(
        transformers=[
            ('numeric', numeric_transformer, numeric_indices),
            ('nominal', categorical_transformer, nominal_indices)],
        remainder='passthrough')

    clf = sklearn.pipeline.make_pipeline(transformer,
                                         sklearn.feature_selection.VarianceThreshold(),
                                         sklearn.ensemble.RandomForestClassifier())
    return clf


model_original = get_model()

flow = openml.flows.sklearn_to_flow(model_original)

run = openml.runs.run_model_on_task(
    model_original,
    task,
    avoid_duplicate_runs=False)
run_original = run.publish()  # this implicitly uploads the flow

run_downloaded = openml.runs.get_run(run_original.run_id)
setup_id = run_downloaded.setup_id
flow = openml.flows.get_flow(run_downloaded.flow_id)

print(flow._to_xml())

model_duplicate = openml.flows.flow_to_sklearn(flow)

run_duplicate = openml.runs.run_model_on_task(
    model_duplicate, task, avoid_duplicate_runs=False)
```

to model the dataset, twice

items.title: Reinstantiating Setup with Column Transformer does not set back the transformer values
items.body:
#### Description
Reinstantiating Model with Column Transformer does not set back the column values

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
```
import logging
import numpy as np
import openml
import sklearn.compose
import sklearn.ensemble
import sklearn.feature_selection
import sklearn.impute
import sklearn.preprocessing

task = openml.tasks.get_task(6)  # use task 2 on live, or task 6 on test


def get_model():
    numeric_transformer = sklearn.pipeline.make_pipeline(
        sklearn.preprocessing.Imputer(),
        sklearn.preprocessing.StandardScaler())

    categorical_transformer = sklearn.pipeline.make_pipeline(
        sklearn.impute.SimpleImputer(strategy='constant', fill_value=-1),
        sklearn.preprocessing.OneHotEncoder(handle_unknown='ignore'))

    nominal_indices = task.get_dataset().get_features_by_type('nominal', [task.target_name])
    numeric_indices = task.get_dataset().get_features_by_type('numeric', [task.target_name])

    transformer = sklearn.compose.ColumnTransformer(
        transformers=[
            ('numeric', numeric_transformer, numeric_indices),
            ('nominal', categorical_transformer, nominal_indices)],
        remainder='passthrough')

    clf = sklearn.pipeline.make_pipeline(transformer,
                                         sklearn.feature_selection.VarianceThreshold(),
                                         sklearn.ensemble.RandomForestClassifier())
    return clf


model_original = get_model()

run = openml.runs.run_model_on_task(
    model_original,
    task,
    avoid_duplicate_runs=False)
run_original = run.publish()  # this implicitly uploads the flow

run_downloaded = openml.runs.get_run(run_original.run_id)
setup_id = run_downloaded.setup_id

model_duplicate = openml.setups.initialize_model(setup_id)

run_duplicate = openml.runs.run_model_on_task(
    model_duplicate, task, avoid_duplicate_runs=False)
```

#### Expected Results
Run executed twice, 

#### Actual Results

items.title: Refactoring: Use Enums for task types
items.body:
#### Description
We currently handle task-type specific logic in if-else statements using the task type ID's, like:

```
    if task.task_type_id == 3:
        do_something()
    else:
        do_something_else()
```

This is very hard to read/maintain and likely to lead to unexpected behavior. 
It would be a lot nicer to replace this by enums, so that we can write:
```
if task.task_type_id == TaskTypeEnum.LEARNING_CURVE:
       do_something()
``` 

One question is where to put the enum definition. Maybe in utils or otherwise in task.py and then imported wherever it is needed.

#### Steps/Code to Reproduce
This happens throughout the codebase, mainly in tasks and runs.
Example:
https://github.com/openml/openml-python/blob/master/openml/runs/functions.py#L115

#### Versions
All versions.

Note that Enums are native in python 3.4+, but have been backported into python 2.7:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/36932/how-can-i-represent-an-enum-in-python

IIUC, we would need an extra dependency (enum34) as long as we support python 2.7.

items.title: Listing functions when not enough results are available
items.body:
It occured to me that the listing function goes bananas when there are less results available that we wanted to obtain. 

I extended the unit test of `test_utils.py`:
```
class OpenMLTaskTest(TestBase):

    def mocked_perform_api_call(call):
        # TODO: JvR: Why is this not a staticmethod?
        url = openml.config.server + '/' + call
        return openml._api_calls._read_url(url)

    @mock.patch('openml._api_calls._perform_api_call', side_effect=mocked_perform_api_call)
    def test_list_all_few_results_available(self, _perform_api_call):
        # we want to make sure that the number of api calls is only 1.
        # Although we have multiple versions of the iris dataset, there is only
        # one with this name/version combination

        datasets = openml.datasets.list_datasets(size=1000,
                                                 data_name='iris',
                                                 data_version=1)
        self.assertEqual(len(datasets), 1)
        self.assertEqual(_perform_api_call.call_count, 1)
```
It actually makes more calls. I will push a fix
